utterances: The Springboks had been barred from international rugby under anti-apartheid sanctions.
And now they were playing New Zealand in the final game for the World Cup in their own country.
And a South African player drop-kicked a goal to win it.
And the player who scored that goal is in Washington today to receive an award from the Search for Common Ground.
And for people who remember the movie, we should say you were played by Scott Eastwood, the son of Clint Eastwood.
You're not the Matt Damon character.
No, that would have been Francois Pienaar, the captain and the forward.
How important to South Africa was that World Cup in 1995?
Well, I think it was a special time for us in our country.
In some ways, a time of uncertainty.
You know, we were a very young democracy and a new president, our first black president.
And we were a nation still divided, really.
And I think that World Cup came at a time for us where it just helped in some little way unite a country around a sports team.
The Common Ground Awards recognize accomplishments in conflict resolution, negotiation, community and peace building - not sports.
During that World Cup, did you feel that you had the burden of those very weighty achievements on your back?
We were just a bunch of young sportsmen wanting to get out on the field and do the best we could.
But we had a common goal and we had a little slogan that we try to live by, and that was: one team one country.
And I think as that World Cup progressed, we could see the demographic breakdown of the supporters changing around us, and obviously a country uniting around this team.
You could see that it was no longer just whites there cheering you on in the stands.
And I think it was partially the fact that we were doing quite well and we were winning.
But I think most importantly, it was Nelson Mandela's support of the team that ensured that everyone supported the team.

I've read that it was a turning point for you to make the trip that many visitors to South Africa, like I did, to Robben Island to see the prison and even the cell where Nelson Mandela had spent so many years.
So we received more than 2,000 correct answers this week.
And our randomly selected winner is Fred Barber of Oswego, N.Y.
Well, I like to think of these after I go to bed, and it helps me fall asleep.

That's what we aim to do - put you to sleep.
